engagementHook.title: Did You Know?
engagementHook.content: You share about 50% of your DNA with each parent, but you also share 50% with your siblings! This is why siblings can look so different - it's all about which genes you inherit from each parent.

contentSections.title: What is Heredity?
contentSections.content: Heredity is the passing of traits from parents to offspring through genetic information. It's the reason why you might have your mother's eyes or your father's height. This fundamental biological process occurs in all living organisms and is essential for the continuation of species.

contentSections.title: Key Definition
contentSections.definition: The scientific study of heredity and variation in living organisms. It examines how traits are passed down through generations and how genetic information is organized, expressed, and regulated.

contentSections.title: Historical Context
contentSections.content:
The modern understanding of heredity began with Gregor Mendel's experiments on pea plants in the 1860s. Though his work was initially overlooked, it laid the foundation for our current understanding of genetics.

Key milestones in genetics:
items: 1866: Mendel publishes his laws of inheritance
1953: Watson and Crick discover DNA structure

gridItems.title: Allele
items: Two per gene (one from each parent)

contentSections.title: Why is Heredity Important?
contentSections.content: Understanding heredity is crucial for many reasons:
items: Medical: Diagnosing inherited disorders, predicting disease risk, personalized medicine
Agriculture: Selective breeding, genetic modification, improving crop yields
Forensics: DNA fingerprinting for criminal investigations
Evolution: Understanding how species change over time
Conservation: Protecting genetic diversity in endangered species

activities.title: Activity 2: Mendel's Legacy
activities.description: Complete the sentences about Gregor Mendel:

definitions: Heredity: The passing of traits from parents to offspring through genetic information
Genetics: The scientific study of heredity and variation in living organisms
Gene: A unit of heredity made of DNA that contains instructions for building proteins
Allele: Different versions of the same gene (e.g., blue eye allele vs brown eye allele)
Phenotype: The observable characteristics of an organism
Genotype: The genetic makeup of an organism - the specific alleles it possesses
keyPoints: Heredity is essential for the continuation of species
Gregor Mendel established the principles of inheritance in 1866
Genes are made of DNA and passed from parents to offspring
Phenotype = observable traits; Genotype = genetic makeup
Understanding heredity has applications in medicine and agriculture

shortAnswer: Understanding heredity helps diagnose inherited disorders, predict disease risk, develop personalized medicine, and identify genetic predispositions to certain conditions.

DNA is the molecule that carries genetic information. A gene is a segment of DNA that codes for a specific trait. An allele is a variant form of a gene. DNA contains genes; genes have different alleles.
